title: Write 10 sentences
subtitle: Write five sentences. They can be as long or as short as you like, but try to make them more than simple descriptive sentences.

title: Translate something from social media
subtitle: Go on Facebook or Tumblr and find a medium-sized post. Translate it into English and post the translation with a link to the original.

title: Have a conversation with a friend on Whatsapp
subtitle: Send a short message or few messages to a friend via Whatsapp / Signal or whatever you use. Tell them what you're up to. Perhaps ask a question or two. Spend the full 20 minutes chatting.

title: Record a video of yourself speaking your language
subtitle: Pick a topic, perhaps from this list (iteslj.org/questions/), and record yourself talking about that topic for 20 minutes. Try to keep speaking, regardless of whether you stumble or forget a word. BONUS: Watch the video back and make a note of things you notice you want to improve or look up as a result.

title: Teach a grammatical feature
subtitle: Find a friend (or willing accomplice) and teach them a grammatical feature of the language you're learning. Make sure it's small enough that you can potentially explain it within 20 minutes.

title: Write a message to a teacher
subtitle: If you've been studying for a year or two, you've probably worked with at least one teacher. Send them an email or message in the language you're studying. Let them know what you're up to and what kinds of things you're studying at the moment. Tell them something you appreciate that they taught you.

title: Skim the top headlines on several news websites
subtitle: Open up a news site that uses the language you're studying. Skim the top headlines and figure out what's happening in the world. Check other sites to see whether they're showing the same stories. BONUS: Tell a friend what you learned from your 20 minutes of news browsing.

title: Read a random wikipedia page in your target language
subtitle: Visit https://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/List_of_Wikipedias, pick the wiki in your language of study, then on the left hand side find a "random article". Read the page for 20 minutes to understand the contents.

title: Read any random text you have near you
subtitle: Read for 20 minutes in any random text you have near you or on your computer / phone. BONUS: Highlight or mark any words you don't understand.

title: Study using Bliubliu
subtitle: Bliubliu is a great site for getting some quick reading practice. (If you don't already have an account, take the 20 minutes to get set up). Pick a topic and let Bliubliu give you short texts. Click the words you know so it knows what level you're at.

title: Write a poem
subtitle: Write a poem. It can be about anything. Just get writing. Don't spend too much time thinking about this one. The point is to write and use your language.

title: Study using Readlang
subtitle: Readlang is a service that allows you to read longer texts, look up words and test yourself on the new words you learnt while reading. (If you don't already have an account, take a few minutes to get set up). Pick a text (either an article you found online, or use the service's own library to suggest a text).

title: Tell a story
subtitle: Talk for 20 minutes without stopping. The challenge is to keep going, to keep making variations on what you're saying, to keep using connector words and phrases. Tell a story about something that happened to you, or maybe explain something that happened years ago. Keep talking.

title: Learn about a well-known figure
subtitle: Research the biography of a well-known figure from the culture or history of the country/people who speak your target language. Use original-language materials. Get the outline of their life story. Start with local-language wikipedia.

title: Zero out your Anki
subtitle: If you don't know what Anki is, start here: https://alexvermeer.com/anki-essentials/. If you're using it already, take these 20 minutes to make progress zeroing out your Anki words for review today.

title: Review your language-learning notebook
subtitle: If you don't have a physical notebook, get one. Write down words you want to know in your target language, words you didn't understand while watching TV and so on. Review the things you've written down during the past week. Add any new words to Anki.

title: Play a few rounds of Pictionary / charades using your target language
subtitle: This requires multiple speakers of your target language, but if you have a group around you, get someone to mime a topic, name of a film or book and try guessing what it is using only your target language. Time yourself.

title: Write a paragraph of text (no repetition edition)
subtitle: Write a paragraph of text without using the same word twice. This is very hard to do in practice, even using your mother-tongue. Try not to think too much, though, and keep writing.

title: Write a paragraph of text (last-letter edition)
subtitle: Write a paragraph of text in which the last letter of the previous word determines the first letter of the next word. This is harder than it sounds. Try not to think too much, though, and keep writing.

title: Read something written over 100 years ago
subtitle: Find something written in your target language that was written over 100 years ago. Notice how the language is different from the kinds of things you read online. Notice any similarities. Enjoy this mental time-travel experience!

title: Read something written over 1000 years ago
subtitle: If your language is old enough, find something written in your target language that was written over 1000 years ago. Notice how the language is different from the kinds of things you read online. Notice any similarities. Enjoy this mental time-travel experience!

title: Talk to fellow language learner
subtitle: Find a friend studying the same language as you, someone at a similar competency level. Have a conversation with them.

title: Take a photo and write a caption
subtitle: Write a caption using your target language. Try to really flex your language muscles. Don't settle for a brief or purely descriptive caption. You have twenty minutes here, so write about what the photo reminds you of, or what thoughts it provokes. Post the photo and the caption to Facebook / Instagram or to your blog.

title: Email a friend
subtitle: Send an email to a friend who speaks your target language. Tell them what you're up to, what you've been studying, or anything else you'd like!

title: Write a summary of the news
subtitle: Take 20 minutes to write down a summary of the important things going on in the news this week. Don't worry too much about the register or formality level of the language. Just try to communicate the important topics. Keep writing.

title: Email a friend about your plans for the coming year
subtitle: Send an email to a friend who speaks your target language. Tell them what you plan to do during the next 6-12 months. Tell them what you're excited about as well as what you're not looking forward to.

title: Read a news article
subtitle: Read through as much of a news article as is possible in 20 minutes. Either visit BBC News' local-language edition or another website published using your target language. If you finish before the time is over, start a new article.

title: Write a summary of an article you read recently
subtitle: Begin by explaining the overall gist of the article, then get into the specifics of how the piece argued its message. Try to use some of the same vocabulary or phrases that were used in the original article. Don't think too much about this; keep writing. Keep communicating.

title: Listen to part of a podcast episode
subtitle: If you don't use a podcast player, maybe spend the time setting this up. Once that's done, do a search online for "[your language] podcasts" and pick a few podcasts that interest you. Subscribe to them using your podcast player, and listen to 10 minutes of an episode. Your player will keep your place in the podcast for when you next listen, so don't worry if the 20 minutes finishes before the end of the episode.

title: Summarise the last film you saw
subtitle: Do this in writing or out loud. Describe the plot. Explain whether you liked the film or not. Explain why. BONUS: Record your summary/review and post it to YouTube. Or if you wrote it down, post it to Lang-8.

title: Summarise the last book you read
subtitle: Do this in writing or out loud. Describe the plot. Explain whether you liked the book or not. Explain why. BONUS: Record your summary/review and post it to YouTube. Or if you wrote it down, post it to Lang-8.

title: Translate a text
subtitle: Take 20 minutes to translate something you read recently. A partial translation is fine. Post your translation somewhere online with a link to the original source text when the 10 minutes are up. BONUS: Consider having a dedicated blog or tumblr where you can post your translations as you do them. This way you'll have a log of your study progress.

title: Record a conversation with a friend
subtitle: Talk about anything you'd like, but don't use anything other than your target language. Once the time is up, post the conversation online to Youtube or Soundcloud. BONUS: Consider doing this more regularly and you'll have your own podcast.

title: Review your language-learning log
subtitle: (If you haven't already set up a language-learning log, take the time to set that up.) Read over the past few weeks of your language-learning. Assess where more focus is needed. Think about what activities you could do to reach that goal. Write down your conclusions.

title: Introduce the city where you live
subtitle: Write a short passage introducing the city where you live to a visitor from the country where your target language is spoken. BONUS: Post this to lang-8, and/or record the passage and post that audio recording to Soundcloud.

title: Translate the lyrics to a favourite song
subtitle: Search for the full lyrics of a song originally written in your target language. Translate the song's lyrics into English (or as much of it as is possible in 20 minutes). BONUS: Post these lyrics and the translation online.

title: Practice some recently-learned words
subtitle: Write some sentences using words that you learned only recently. Post these practice sentences to Lang-8 to make sure that you're using the words in the right way / context.

title: Brainstorm a topic
subtitle: Brainstorm two or three dozen words in English related to a random topic you pick. Don't take more than 2 or 3 minutes for this task. Then for the rest of the time, try to translate the words into your target language. Note which words you don't know, and after the time is up, look them up in a dictionary.

title: Go for a short walk
subtitle: Walk around the block or walk around the area where you're studying/based. As you walk, have an inner monologue in which you describe everything you see around you. Keep talking to yourself; don't use English. When you get back, make a note of the words you were unable to recall.

title: Watch a news report
subtitle: Search YouTube for a news report or short film about any topic that interests you. Make sure it is in your target language. Watch the video.

title: Research a topic that interests you
subtitle: Use only sources in your target language. Read a variety of sources. Start to figure out the outlines of that topic.

title: Summarise something you learnt recently
subtitle: Pick something you learnt or researched recently. Summarise the important points about that topic or issue. Summarise the main sources you used to come to these conclusions. BONUS: Post your summary to Lang-8 or your blog for feedback.

title: Tell a friend about something you learnt recently
subtitle: Pick something you learnt or researched recently. Summarise the important points about that topic or issue. Summarise the main sources you used to come to these conclusions. BONUS: Record it and post your conversation to YouTube or Soundcloud for feedback.

title: Look at a frequency list
subtitle: Frequency vocabulary lists are lists of words organised by the frequency which they are generally used. Search online for "[your language] frequency vocabulary list" and look to see if there are any of the most frequent words that you don't know. Make a note of the words that you struggle to understand.

title: Think about conversation topics
subtitle: Visit iteslj.org/questions/ and pick a topic. Look at the questions. Imagine you had to answer the questions in your target language. What vocabulary would you need to know to be able to answer those questions? Make a note of these missing words.

title: Search for a job
subtitle: Browse job-search sites using your target language. Search for careers or jobs that interest you. Read some of descriptions and requirements of the jobs on offer.

title: Teach something
subtitle: Think of something you know, but a friend doesn't know. Take twenty minutes to teach that topic or skill to your friend, using only your target language.

title: Teach something online
subtitle: Think of something you know. Record a video to YouTube in which you teach that topic or skill, using only your target language. Don't think about this too much. Take a minute or two to sketch out a rough structure and then just get talking.

title: Write 100 words
subtitle: Write about what you did during the past 12 months.

title: Write 100 words
subtitle: Write about what you want to do during the coming 12 months.

title: Write 100 words
subtitle: Write about what you consider to be the qualities possessed by a good leader.

title: Write 100 words
subtitle: Describe earth and human society to a visiting alien.

title: Write 100 words
subtitle: Write a bullet point list of why you're studying your target language (using that target language).

title: Read up on difficult grammar
subtitle: Take some time to read up on a grammar point that you know you find difficult but always put off really taking the time to understand. Try to get to the point where you understand what's going on / how it works. BONUS: Once you understand, try teaching it to someone else. This will cement your understanding.

title: Summarise a short film or documentary
subtitle: Recall the contents of a short film or documentary you watched recently. Ideally you'll have watched it in your target language. Write a summary of that film or documentary, starting with the big ideas and slowly adding in the more intricate points. End by analysing the content, and/or expressing your opinion.

title: Write a book review
subtitle: Write a short review in your target language. First summarise the content of the book, then state what you thought about it. Finally, explain how it fits in the context of other things you've read or heard.

title: Write some fiction
subtitle: Start writing a short story in your target language. Don't worry about the quality for now. Just focus on telling a story as best you can, using the full extent of your language.

title: Desert Island Scenario
subtitle: You're stuck on a desert island. Write or speak out loud (ideally to someone else) a description of how you'd deal with this situation. Describe how you'd feel.

title: Broken Down Car Scenario
subtitle: You are driving in a remote area during heavy winter and your car breaks down. You don't know which way to go to find help, but if you stay out in the cold you probably won't survive. Write or speak out loud (ideally to someone else) a description of how you'd deal with this situation. Describe how you'd feel.

title: Give Back
subtitle: Write a short post online (on Facebook, Tumblr or your blog) explaining something that you struggled to learn recently. Share the lessons of how you managed to deal with this and surmount your difficulties.

title: Open Source Software Translation
subtitle: Do a search online for "[your language] volunteer translation opportunities" and you will probably find some people looking for volunteer help translating materials. Some open-source software projects will have specific tools to help you contribute.

title: Write some comprehension questions
subtitle: Use an article you recently read as the basis for this exercise. Write 5-10 comprehension questions based on the content of the article in your target language. BONUS: Post them on your blog or on Facebook along with the original article for others to use.

title: Write a guide to a grammar feature
subtitle: Write a short guide to a particular feature of grammar in your target language. Feel free to write it in your mother-tongue. BONUS: Post this grammar guide on your blog or even on Facebook or Tumblr.

title: Write a letter to your past self
subtitle: Imagine you could write a short note to your past self, to the person you were a few years ago (or more). What would you say? Write a note to this past self.

title: Write a letter to your future self
subtitle: Imagine you could write a short note to your future self, to the person you you will become in a few years (or more). What would you say? Write a note to this future self.

title: Write a recipe
subtitle: Write a recipe in your target language for a meal you cook often. List the ingredients first and then the steps you need to take to prepare the food.

title: Take a dictation
subtitle: Open up a video in Arabic on YouTube. Depending on your level / confidence, adjust the speed of the video to something comfortable enough so that you can take dictation. You have two options: 1) take notes that are detailed enough that you can explain the contents to someone else or 2) take a word-for-word dictation.

title: Do some video description
subtitle: Open up a video in Arabic on YouTube. Turn off the sound or mute your computer/phone. Start talking out loud, describing what is happening as images continue to change in the video. Imagine you are describing it to someone who can't see, or who isn't watching the video with you.

title: DictionaryBot
subtitle: Find a passage of text that you've read recently, or that you find easy to read. Go through the text and, as you stop by each word, define the term using your target language. You probably won't get very far into the text by the time expires, but make sure not to use any English or anything that isn't your target language to explain the definitions of each word.

title: Make a new city plan
subtitle: Your city or the place where you live probably has some problems it needs fixing. Take this time to outline and then write a city plan (in your target language) that could be taken and used to fix the problems. Begin each paragraph by stating the specific problem you want to solve, and then end with the solution. BONUS: Post this on lang-8 (http://www.lang-8.com/) and get corrections!.

title: Creating stories from pictures
subtitle: Find a magazine or advertisement leaflet or some other such material. You could even go online to the website of IKEA (http://www.ikea.com). As you start looking through the pictures, start talking about the people and the things you see. Early on, start labelling the items, but then you should also eventually start imagining scenarios about the lives of the people in the pictures. Or if there is nobody in the picture, think about why they are absent. Say it all out loud.
